author: DeaconStanJesusMan

description.text:
This is a proof of concept manual positioner/translation stage for optics or whatever precise things you need to place/move around. You do need some hardware to build it, but it is pretty low cost compared to a commercial version. I am just using a standard nut and screw to move the stage, but it should be pretty straightforward to put in a more precision screw. I do plan to put in a ultra fine pitch screw into one of them in the future, but in my experience for many applications standard thread screws should be adequate. I have tried my best to make the source code relatively editable and at least understandable. I am not a professional programmer or anything, so design patterns are not my forte. I wanted to make it easily changeable for people to use whatever materials they have available. I got most of them from mcmaster, but I am sure ace or a local hardware store should have everything you need. In the following list I have the mcmaster carr part number so you can see what it is. Materials needed (as configured):
2x Springs with ID > 3/16" (9657K66)
2x dowel pins with 3/16" diameter and 3" length (98381A525)
4x bronze oil impregnated bushings (6338K311)
7x M3 nut
1x M3 screw ~ 30-40mm length.
6x M3 screw 16mm length
1x small square of tape(i used kapton) to protect plastic I recommend using slightly longer springs and also maybe slightly larger diameter and k. it takes a while to get things to fit smoothly, but it should work pretty nice once you get it together. Using the 4 bushings which fit perfectly on the dowels constrains the motion well. There is no noticeable unwanted angular movement. I want to try printing one off that does not use bushings and slides directly on the plastic. I also want to experiment with nutserts because tapping 3d printed parts is kind of wonky. The files I provided are optimized for my printer, so there may be some weird stuff(mainly hole size). Feel free to edit the source code to make sure things fit snug. Luckily this thing prints pretty quickly. I am also working on making the source a bit cleaner, but I was excited about how well this stage worked and wanted to get it out there.

• Print off both end plates the platform as the STL has them. The platform should be printed so the holes are in the Z direction. I used 0.3mm layer height.

  • This is probably a good time to tap the holes and place a small square of kapton tape in the middle of one of the edges of the platform so that the screw can rotate nicely on it.

  • insert a hex nut into the hole on the end plate with a hole. tighten a screw into the hex nut to bring it in tight. It should fit tight, but if you are worried a dab of glue didnt hurt anyone.

  • Insert the Dowels into the other endplate. Add the springs and then 2 bushings to either dowel(1 each). Then add the platform and the other bushings. press the threaded endplate into the dowel.

  • Press the bushings into the platform by sliding it up and down on the dowels. Make sure that things move relatively smoothly. You basically want to make sure that the spring can push the platform back to its original position.

  • Once you are sure everything slides nicely measure the distance between the endplates and edit the scad file to set baseL to this value in mm. It should have automatically created the right length, but if for whatever reason things don't work try editing it. Print the base

  • attach the base with those nimble fingers of yours with the remaining screws

comments.text: This is very cool. McMaster is not that great as a source for micro-scale components (M2, M1.6, etc). Most industrial supply places only go down to M3. With M2-.4 threaded rod and a 1.8 degree stepper motor you get a linear movement resolution of 2um. A good source for the M2 and smaller stuff is Scale Hardware - got some M2 stuff from them in brass recently for a similar project. http://scalehardware.com/http://scalehardware.com/

title: Pretty Good Bed Leveling & Z-Stop Kit for Makerfarm Pegasus

description.text:
This is a kit to improve the Makerfarm Pegasus printer's bed leveling. It requires only an M3 bolt driver. It includes a set of nut/spring traps for the heat bed mount, and a Z-axis end stop which is much more accessible. I don't have a wooden heat bed mount, but I included a set of traps for one, assuming the mounting holes are offset in the same dimensions.

The Z-stop arm uses the HammerNut from CaptainObvious (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:245103), which makes this retro-fittable. No dissassembly is required to change out the end stop.

From the trap-alum or trap-wood STL file, you'll get:
1) Rectangle-ish nut & spring trap for the bottom of the bed (QTY 4)
2) Round spring cap for the top of the spring (QTY 4)

From the zstop-arm STL file, you'll get:
3) Long t-nut "bar" for the Z-axis adjustment screw, with two holes (QTY 1)
4) Angled arm for the end stop switch, with the HammerNut on one end, and a mounting spot for the switch on the other (QTY 1)

See below for assembly tips.

License is inherited from CaptainObvious' HammerNut.

Printer:

Makerfarm Pegasus 10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100% for strength

Assembly

Move your z-axis up a few inches to get some room to work.
Remove the original Z-axis adjuster and retain the long M3 screw. (I had a leftover t-nut in the rail, which I just bolted out of the way at the bottom.)
Insert the reclaimed M3 bolt through one hole of the long t-nut. No tapping should be required. The t-nut will be "pointing" up when installed, so be sure that the driver will be on the top.
Install the t-nut bar into the bottom of the x-axis extrusion near the X-axis motor, poking out about 15mm or so. (See photos.) Use a short M3 bolt to secure it into the rail using the hole in the other end of the bar. You should be able to reach the z-axis adjustment bolt from the top front of the motor mount area.
Next, secure the endstop switch to the angled arm. The switch should be on the side opposite from the HammerNut (see photos). This way, when the arm is mounted to the vertical Z-axis rail, it will line up to the adjustement screw we installed.
To install the switch arm, line it up against the vertical axis and insert the HammerNut into the slot. Rotate the arm to the right to fit the nut in place. The arm should extend out to the right, just above the Z motor. Secure the arm with another short M3 screw.
(This is one spot which could be improved.... The arm can't be torqued very hard. It should be okay as long as your switch works.)
Install the bed traps and spring cups. The bottom trap will hold an M3 lock nut.

Adjustment t-nut bar Endstop switch arm

description.text:
This is the Outlaw Star! The XGP-15A2 from the anime series Outlaw Star that was shown on Toonami in 2001. That show was a big part of my childhood and still one of my favorite shows. After being quoted $200 for just the model of the Outlaw Star I decided to build one myself and give it out to you guys for free! I dedicate this model to those fans who loved this ship as much as I did!

There's 3 versions (actually 4);

-The larger detailed version starts with an L in the file name (with 2 versions of the main body = one piece or split into 2 pieces for ease of printing). You'll need to print out 4 engines, 2 horizontal fins, and 2 vertical fins

A medium size version that's cut in half starting with an M in the file name

and a full size complete version. (onepiece.stl)

I printed my model at 200% scale. And sorry for any mistakes in the geometry... this is only the second 3D model I've ever made.
Blender

Made using OpenSCAD Here is the code I used to make it: module window()
{
difference()
{ difference() { cube([12,80,12],center=true); translate([0,-40,0]) cube([10,3,10],center=true); } translate([0,20,0]) cube([13,50,13],center=true); } }
module support()
{ color([1,0,0]) translate([0,35,0]) cylinder(r=3,h=12); }
module wall()
{
for (i = [0:20])
{
translate([i12,0,0])
window();
}
}
module wall_support()
{
for (i = [0:20])
{
translate([i12,-70,0])
support();
translate([i*12,-60,0])
support();
}
}
module corner_support()
{
for (i= [0:15])
{ rotate(i*14+180,v=[0,0,1]) support(); }
}
module corner()
{
for (i= [0:15])
{ rotate(i*14,v=[0,0,1]) window(); }
}
module wing()
{
wall();
translate([248,-40,0])
rotate([0,0,-90])
corner();
}
module wing_support()
{
wall_support();
translate([248,-40,0])
rotate([0,0,-90])
corner_support();
}
module floor()
{
wing();
translate([243,-30,0])
rotate([0,0,120])
wing();
translate([148,195,0])
rotate([0,0,240])
wing();
}
module floor_support()
{
wing_support();
translate([243,-30,0])
rotate([0,0,120])
wing_support();
translate([148,195,0])
rotate([0,0,240])
wing_support();
}
for(i=[0:40])
{
translate([0,0,i12+18])
floor();
}
floor_support();
color([1,0,0])
translate([-8,0,0])
cylinder(r=25,h=4012+24);
color([1,0,0])
translate([250,-40,0])
cylinder(r=25,h=4012+24);
color([1,0,0])
translate([154,205,0])
cylinder(r=25,h=4012+24); difference()
{
color([1,1,1],1)
translate([120,110,(4012+24)/2])
cube([250,250,4012+24],center=true);
union()
{
translate([290,160,(4012+24)/2])
color([1,0,1],.5)
rotate([0,0,120])
cube([350,250,4012+24],center=true);
translate([-30,160,(4012+24)/2])
color([1,0,1],.5)
rotate([0,0,240])
cube([350,250,4012+24],center=true);
}
}

I made this in OpenScad by creating one window module and then repeating it for the walls and corners.  
I plan to add in the evaporator units at the top and the drive and parking garage in the future.

description.text:
This is an adapter to allow the following memory foam armrests to work on a Herman Miller Aeron:
http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00NJBCPVE

Tools Needed

  • 2x 1/4in - 20 x 3/4in Oval Head Phillips
  • 2x 1/4in - 20 x 1 1/4in Oval Head Phillips
  • 4x 1/4in - 20 x 1/2in Round Head Phillips
  • 2x 1/4in - 20 nuts

Links to Tools (~$3)

  • http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt/202706494
  • http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt/204274850
  • http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt/204274641

Assembly

  1. Line up center screw hole with the second hole on the armrest, starting from the top.
  2. Line up other screw hole with the third hole on the armrest.
  3. Use two 1/2in screws to attach.
  4. Insert nut into end slot on adapter.
  5. Attach armrest to chair using 3/4in screw on front and 1 1/4in on back.

This was based on Eccentric Sphere Gears (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6499). I modified the SCAD files so that it would use pins instead of screws to secure the gears to the center piece and instead of a sphere a dodecahedron is used. Also, this one is not eccentric so that the gears spin without the object dramatically changing shape. The STL files are already plated for printing (it can be done in 3 prints). Also, each piece is also attached separately (although differently scaled). Use the ddhedron_not_printable.stl file to see how the components fit together. It's not obvious after all the parts are printed.

description.text:
Tubas are hard to carry back and forth on a school bus or in a backpack. So, school-age tuba players often have a tuba at home and one at school. But they also often have a favorite mouthpiece that they carry back and forth. And school-age kids' backpacks are a harsh and scary environment.

So, this case provides protection from scratches and dings. It has a friction-fit slip-on lid and an air hole to keep things from getting too funky (at least when you're not playing).

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

ORION Delta 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed the lid in Soft PLA, which makes it flex and stay on nicely. My settings still probably need tweaking - this was the first real object I printed with it - but they are:

  • Bed temp: 25 C
  • Extruder temp: 230 C
  • Speed, infill & perimeters: 20 mm/s
  • Fan: off
  • Extrusion multiplier: 1.05

The angle of the top lip of the base may make the lid stay decently even if it's made from a more rigid plastic like PLA or ABS. Let me know if you try it!

I first tried this trombone mouthpiece customizer, but found that it didn't support dimensions large enough for a tuba mouthpiece.

I then tried this customized version of that project, with a 118% scale factor as recommended. It printed decently, but didn't fit the Bach mouthpieces I have - the diameter was too small in some key places. I realized that these tuba mouthpieces aren't just scaled-up versions of trombone mouthpieces; the profile is fairly different.

Then I tried using a similar approach to ckirby's, using Bezier curves. I measured the diameter of the mouthpiece at various heights, entered those coordinates into my OpenSCAD script, and tried to fit the curve to those points. But I got frustrated with that process - moving points in and out repeatedly, with each modification to one part of the curve influencing other parts. It seemed hard to get the curve to converge where I wanted it.

So, I wrote a cubic spline library, and used that. I used the "preview profile" mode in the script (see picture below) to adjust the spline (blue) to fit the measured points (in red). Because cubic splines pass exactly through their control points, this was really straightforward to do.

The libraries are included in the source ZIP file, and are also available on GitHub.

Then leave it for a few hours to set.

Here are two triangle matching puzzles each composed of six equilateral triangles. The solved puzzles are hexagons containing 40-50 complete cats. A key is provided. Squares containing the cats were constructed using images from thing:54736 - Cat Coasters 01. Plane groups P1 and P2 were used. Group P1 has no symmetry while group P2 has a 2 fold axis at the origin. The point where the six triangles meet was placed at the origin with the following effect: Puzzle p1 all six triangles are different.
Puzzle p2 the triangles occur in pairs and there are three different kinds of triangles. The P1 puzzle is provided in two stl files each of which contains 3 triangles. The P2 puzzle is provided in one stl file which contains 3 triangles. It needs to be printed twice. The generating squares are included together with the openSCAD code that divides the squares into triangles. The square in thing:149870, Child's Puzzle 4, is the same size making it possible to convert Child's Puzzle 4 to a triangular form and these puzzles to square forms.

The tiles are best printed directly on the build platform.  
The absent or simple symmetry and the many cats keep these puzzle from being trivial.  
The regular rows of cats simplify the solution of the P1 puzzle.  
The P2 puzzle can be solved quickly if one recognizes that it contain identical triangles which must be related by symmetry; not so quickly if the triangles are all thought to be different.

title: DashCam T slot adapter to Garmin

description.text:
I was given a cheap dash cam for a gift, and the cheap suction cup broke. So I had an old Garmin GPS and salvaged the suction cup post with ball, made the adapter and presto. Working yet again! Very simple and could use some improvements which I plan on but heck for now it gets it back up.

No supports are needed it has integrated supports for the T, easy breakaway. You may or may not need to file a little down, depending on the device its for.

This particular dashcam was for the Cyclops HD Unit. I have to say I'm pleased with the way it turned out. Prints fine it Nylon, ABS, and PLA. With Nylon and ABS you will need rafts as there is a very small surface for contact on the rim.

author: agilliam

description.text:
Gadget freaks need batteries... Lots of batteries! So the sensible thing to do is to use a rechargeable batteries and to keep a stock of charged batteries ready for action. If you like me keep your charged batteries in a drawer or box, you will know that they roll around, short one another out and of course you never have any idea as to which batteries have been charged first and last. Add in a few other items, i.e. a set of keys or two, an old spare mobile phone and charger and a few favourite take-out menus and finding those batteries during for instance a power cut becomes problematic also. I was not happy with this and put my mind to coming up with a solution. Well here it is... The Parametric Cylindrical Battery Dispenser will create a vertical storage solution for all your cylindrical battery storage needs. It contains dimensions to create AA and AAA sized dispensers but as it is near fully parametric, you can create in theory a dispenser for just about any cylindrical battery. Limitations of your 3d Printer though are likely to restrict you to smaller battery sizes. The Parametric Cylindrical Battery Dispenser prints in two halves to make it as easy as possible to print (little to no overhangs). I found the best results were to use 50% infill and 3 additional shells on my Prusa using PLA, YMMV. The Openscad file will generate several different styles of dispenser depending on the options you pick:

  • The simplest design that comprises just two runners. This was my original design and I have printed it. It works well enough, but I found it to be a little flimsy when secured to a vertical surface.

  • The tabbed version (main photo) which is the version I decided on using for my own battery dispensers. This is has nice broad mounting tabs at the rear of the dispenser that can be sized to match double sided sticky foam. Perfect for mounting on the inside of cupboards etc.

  • The mounting plate version (untested). This version has a mounting plate that is split into two halves, Theoretically, it should make it easier to space the two halves of the dispenser to each other but it uses more plastic and I don't think its as handsome as the others

  • Spare runners. (unfinished) These are functional, but only match the simplest design of dispenser. As I can get a reasonably sized dispenser to print on my Prusa (big enough to hold 8 AA batteries)I don't really need this now. I left it in as an option though.

  • Calibration piece. There is also an option to create a small segment of one half of the dispenser. Print this to double check that the dimensions you set print well on your printer
    • There are also options to add mounting holes if you are using either the tabbed or back-plated styles of dispenser. The mounting holes are nominal values right now, so you will have to set the variables to values that match your screw dimensions and printer. I am marking this item as finished as it exceeds all my cylindrical battery vertical storage requirements but you may have other improvements you wish to make. If so I apologise for the code, I am positive it could be better optimised.

• Download the Battery_holder.scad file and open it with OpenScad.

  • Adjust the variables at the start of the file to produce the style and size of dispenser that you require. I have commented the variables as best as I can. Ask questions in the comments if you get stuck.

  • It would be wise to set the calibrate option to true. This will create a small calibration piece for you to check your options.

  • Export your calibration piece to the slicer of your choice and print a test piece. If all works well go back and set calibrate to false. You should now be able to create both halves of the dispenser.

  • Export and print your dispenser. Mount it to the inside of a cupboard door or another suitable surface and fill it with charged batteries.

  • Remove the batteries from the bottom of the dispenser as you need them safe in the knowledge the batteries there have not been shorted and are the ones needing used first.
    • Available Parameters Calibration
    calibrate Mount Tab Variables mount_tab_opt
    mount_tab_height
    mount_tab_thickness Back Plate Variables back_plate
    back_plate_holes_pan
    back_plate_thickness Mounting Holes Dimensions and Shape

title: HSP TRIBESHEAD Truggy Roll Cage for FPV LED

description.text:
Update 2016-07-02 Having fun with Truggy and RunCamHD on 3S.
https://youtu.be/lzIVX7pFbnc

Update 2016-04-27 i draw and printed parts which i broke. Will see how the holds up in outdoor test. Any way it's better then just wait for replacement parts. Also added pictures with wheel in place.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1522778

I want to mount an FPV Gear and camera + some LEDs on my Truggy. But didn't know where to do it. And then i saw Traxxas E-Revo roll cage. So i thought it will be a good platform for mounting whatever you want on your car. So i designed this kind of Roll Cage. It's quite robust if you running on some soft track and not hitting the concrete road edging like i did.(3 times actually).
Anyway, it was made for slow FPV rides, not bashing.
You can choose the plates for your needs(LEDs, FPV stuff, camera). You can turn them upside down if you need so.
Also added simple bumpers and rhino style bumpers if some one whats to print only them.
So far i found 3 weak points
First is my driving skills. This was my first run and on 3S in the town. I should choose some softer track for practice.
Second is my transmitter for air models, not cars.
And the third is this damn concrete road edging. Lol.
Will modify and add some plates for different needs.
To build this you will need
18-30 M3x16 bolts + washers (depending on which plates you want to use or how many of them),
126mm M6 threaded rod,
2 washers and 2 M6 locking nuts for this rod,
2 clips to hold the cage in the back.
On the bottom used 4 original countersunk screws.

Just remember! Don't hit the concrete! Lol.
Sorry for the photos with broken wheel. Will try to print broken parts while waiting new ones.- Done!
Check the "disaster driving skills" video.
https://youtu.be/L75X3BWgvM8

If you like my work, if you want to see new designs, you can donate any amount for a filament.

No

0.2

30%

RIP Prince - 1958 - 2016

Kiss and Stare are two of my favorites songs from Prince. I am also a fan of Dave Chapelle's Skits about Prince and his blouses. But I didn't really knew well. But I saw some of his performances and listened to all of my parents ramble about him and I felt that his music had a huge impact to many people. My dad taught me how to play Purple Rain on the guitar, which led me to love music.

So here is a reminder of a great performer, and an artist that now bites the dust.

Still a work in progress. I still need to print one of these and double check all the dimensions and location of the 4 screw holes.

Wanted a way to use an empty drive bay to hold an arduino or raspi ( or both) computer. Have the idea to use the smaller computers to interface to the real world, or to automate downloads from the internet, or other mass actions, while saving power by not running the desktop computer all the time. But to use the keyboard and display of the bigger computer along with some software to configure the smaller computers easily.

A small LCD display, a few LEDs and a switch or rotary switch or two will be the interface for the small computer. I also want the small computer to be able to switch on the main computer at set times.

Wondering if I can use the trickle charge for wake on lan power to run the add on computers even if the desktop looks like it is powered off. Add in a small lion battery with a charge circuit to make sure this small computer can power itself for a while even if the wall power goes off.

Open scad.

I created a large block by measuring a drive tray I had for a removable hard drive with a set of digital calipers. I also got the location of the mounting holes by measuring this drive tray. then I used a difference command to removed the screw holes, and places for the lcd, led, and switches on the front panel. I made a hex pattern and differenced that from the floor of the sled.

left to do

make a hole in the back for power and usb connections. Add mounts for arduino mini pro, raspi 2 and pi zero. Add mounts for fan? Add a top that is like the bottom?

description.text:
My young boy (1 year old) was getting closer and closer from being able to unlatch the downstairs door.

I was kind of worried, so a morning I decided to (very) quickly design this double security for the door latch.

The design is not bad, but could be better. I was quite in a hurry.

I would like, first, to make sure it isn't possible to remove the elastic.
Secondly, It is kind of getting annoying to have to push back on my device to "re-latch" the door. Maybe a pivoting portion (or complete system) would allow the spring loaded lock not to be in the way when reclosing the door latch.

But it is not that bad. :)

Hope this could help someone!

I forget, I used large elastic band, but this was designed for smaller ones. I did not have any in hands at that moment.

I also use double sided tape for mounting.

description.text:
This is a narrow version of a tool holder inspired by the thing mentioned above in the ancestry. I liked that thing with the caveat that when I have the gen4 interface hooked onto the front of my ToM, there wasn't enough room to hang my tools too. So, I took inspiration from the original thing, redrew it and made two design changes:
  • rotate on Z axis 90 degrees to make a narrow surface.
  • added a second level so that my tools would have more support and be less likely to fall out. The L-bend of my hex keys just loved to slip through the single holes. Not anymore.

Final iteration of a fun learning project.

A teacher needed to put a battery operated LED tealight onto the end of a long 3/8" dowel rod. Since this is for small children glue or tape would not survive long enough to practice and actually still have them for three days of a show.
The needs were:

  • had to be sturdy enough to be reused frequently and even dropped often.
  • black
  • space for the on switch
  • as little assembly as possible (i.e. glueing, drilling, screwing)
  • cheap

A 2lb spool of ABS was $32
To create 35 of these I used 276 grams of material... $9.73 or about 28 cents a unit. pretty cheap, I guess I could have cut down on some of the material in the cup but then I don't think it would have survived as well.
The addition of the hole for the switch made it so that each print had to be trimmed. the first three layers printing with no supports were always a bit messed up.
But on this final product there is no glue, drilling, or anything additional. You just push it onto the end of the dowel rod and the tiny ridges inside keep it tight. Same goes for the cup for the tealight. The addition of a small interior ring keeps the tealight secure.

Final STL and Open SCAD file are on here. I just learned SCAD for this project so if someone wants to give me some pointers I would welcome it!!

As you can see in the picture, I prefer to keep my filament rolls off the machine, many people mount them to the top of the gantry, Not Good, a lot of inertial weight at the top can cause harmonic vibration across the gantry, especially during fills, when there is rapid head movement over repetitive routes.

The guides are designed for 4mm O.D PTFE tube and mount to existing bolt holes in the side frames of the Gantry, you will need slightly longer 3mm Cap bolts, or countersink the hole.

If you need different size outside diameter, please let me know, see what can be done.

remixed_from.title: Bike phone holder (Nexus 5 & others; FreeCAD file included)

description.text:
Remixed of the original to fit a Sony Xperia SP.

The phone is 68mm wide with no case and I've used 63.5mm in constrain33 for a snug fit. Could be easily adapted to any phone if you do the math.
I made this to hold a 3 cell Li-ion battery in place for a project that I am helping on.

print_settings.Notes:: The back took just under 3 hours to print in translucent blue PLA that roughly matches the blue color of the Canon PowerShot that mounts on it. The 75mm focal length front also took about 3 hours to print, but in black PLA. Both the front and back should be done with at least two layers of outer shell; I tried using 1 layer, but rigidity simply wasn't good enough and lightproofing would have been more difficult. The screw that fits the tripod socket of the ELPH 115 IS takes very little time to print (I used white PLA), but it is a separate print to ensure the threads are as nice as possible.

title: Camera Obscura for Canon PowerShot ELPH115IS

description.text:
Just in time for me to use it for Worldwide Pinhole Photography Day, here's a rather large attachment that allows a Canon PowerShot ELPH 115 IS to be used to capture pinhole images. To be more precise, it allows that little Canon to capture whatever image is projected onto the 150mm diagonal screen built-into the unit, and the front section described here makes that screen the target of a pinhole obscura.

Now you're probably wondering why use that Canon compact. Well, pinhole resolution is fundamentally limited by the size of the image, so this big screen (roughly the size of a 4x5 film sheet) offers much better resolution than you can get directly using a pinhole with a small digital sensor. However, this particular Canon has the extra benefit that despite being a cheap and tiny 16MP camera, it can run CHDK -- which means it can be programmed to do an HDR capture sequence that can easily handle the huge dynamic range caused by light falloff in an ultrawide pinhole image. The photos of the pond, dandelions, and my 101-year-old aunt were all HDR sequences done with this rig.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

only where needed

Notes:

The back took just under 3 hours to print in translucent blue PLA that roughly matches the blue color of the Canon PowerShot that mounts on it. The 75mm focal length front also took about 3 hours to print, but in black PLA. Both the front and back should be done with at least two layers of outer shell; I tried using 1 layer, but rigidity simply wasn't good enough and lightproofing would have been more difficult. The screw that fits the tripod socket of the ELPH 115 IS takes very little time to print (I used white PLA), but it is a separate print to ensure the threads are as nice as possible.

Putting it all together

Translucent PLA is a very bad choice indeed for camera parts that are supposed to be opaque. However, this is handled by a couple of coats of flat black latex paint on the inside. This creates an effective light seal, but leaves the body with a very attractive translucent sheen. That said, I do see a tiny bit of blue leakage where direct sun is involved, so maybe it's time to give a 3rd coat? The text label on the body should also be painted white so it will stand-out better and be more readable. The front and screw need no painting, although again there is no reason you couldn't paint the inside of the front... and I would have if the PLA black used had not been so opaque by itself.

Once those parts are done, you need two other things before you screw the unit together: an appropriate screen for the obscura and a pinhole.

The screen used here is simply some waxed tracing paper. The paper was cut to fit over the mask on the 3D-printed back and then held in place using blue painter's tape to hold it in place by the edges. This screen gives a very heavy texture, which reduces resolution somewhat; a thin plastic diffuser sheet would produce better images.

The pinhole can be made any number of ways, but precision counts. I tested using aluminum duct tape with a pinhole, but the hole produced was sloppy. Instead, I cut apart a Dr. Pepper soda can to get a piece of thin aluminum (which is still much more solid than the duct tape). I used my CNC engraver to drill a roughly 0.4mm hole as the pinhole (overkill, but I had the CNC loaded with an appropriate bit anyway); it produced a nicely circular hole with a clean edge. I then sanded both sides of the aluminum scrap to remove any coatings and further ensure the pinhole edge was clean. Finally, I used a Q-tip to brush Aluminum Black on the pinhole metal, producing a good approximation to a matte-black anodized finish. Finally, I used blue painter's tape to tape it into position from the inside of the front.

Once all the parts are done, simply screw the front all the way onto the back. It can be a little tricky to get the thread started, but it works pretty smoothly and securely. Finally, mount the Canon PowerShot ELPH155IS on the back and use the printed screw to lock it there by its tripod socket.

Using the camera

Using the camera is pretty easy. The pinhole gives a field of view roughly comparable to a 24mm ultrawide lens on a full-frame DSLR, and everything is in focus (sort-of), so don't be afraid to get close to your subject. Remember that the PowerShot is always photographing the screen, so leave it in close-up mode no matter what distance the real subject is at. Simply turn the PowerShot on, frame your shot using the rear LCD, and take a photo... in theory.

In practice, the metering will get you a shot that is at least 3 stops underexposed because the pinhole image is much brighter in the center -- and the camera only allows +/-2 stop exposure compensation. However, this is where the ability to use CHDK comes in handy. You can get CHDK for free from http://chdk.wikia.com/wiki/CHDK . Not only does it provide for manual exposure overrides, but you can also run Lua scripts for HDR (high dynamic range) capture that can get good detail everywhere, and then you can even-out the vignetting in postprocessing. For the examples here, I used a simple script to capture 3-5 image HDR sequences and then did a very crude tone mapping using layers in GIMP.

Keep in mind that the pinhole is producing a very dark image, so expect long exposures. The Obscura has a tripod socket that can be used to mount it for long exposures -- although I found the tripod socket had a little play in use, so be careful about trusting it to hold the camera firmly. Bracing the camera works too; sometimes hand holding works, but expect some motion blur.

Long exposures tend to eat batteries, and shooting HDR sequences can fill memory cards quickly. Note that the camera mount to the Obscura allows the SD card/battery compartment door to be opened with the camera attached, and you can swap memory cards that way, but you can't get the battery out while the camera is mounted on the Obscura.

This was designed using OpenSCAD. First the minimum focus distance was determined -- then the coverage. The dimensions were rounded-up to approximate a 4x5 screen. In fact, the Obscura back can be used with other fronts to mount not only pinholes of various focal lengths, but also standard lenses intended to cover the 4x5 format.

author: FXTDaver

description.text:
This was my first attempt at sculpting a creature bust. It's a bit basic, but it was fun to sculpt!

(IF YOU DON'T OWN A PRINTER- With all my models, I highly recommend downloading the model file, and reuploading it onto 3DHubs. Search for a local printer, or a printer that can ship prints to you, and print in the highest resolution possible! Form 2 and the Solus at at least 25 micron resloution work really well with my models! Be sure to post pics of your makes! I'd love to see them.)

This is a 3D printed optimized version of the offical NASA 3D model of the Juno spacecraft. The model was designed in Tinkercad. You can find the Tinkercad model here.

Some assembly is required after printing.

When printed, a single solar wing measures 2 inches across, and the model is approximately 4.5 inches in diameter. A real Juno solar wing is about 30 feet long, making the printed model a 1:180 scale.

The Juno mission is a NASA mission to Jupiter, arriving on July 4, 2016. The mission website is located here.

Printer:

DIY Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Step 1: Setup

Orient the model with the magnetometer (the one wing that is different) facing up.

You will need either superglue or acetone to attach the components together.

Step 2: Attach the High Gain Antenna assembly

Glue (using superglue) or weld (using acetone) the high gain antenna assembly onto the center of the main spacecraft.

The two thruster towers should face left and right, and the instruments (the little bumps) should face down.

Step 3: Attach the large MWR antenna

Glue or weld the large microwave radiometer (MWR) antenna onto the top left side of the main spacecraft body as shown

Step 4: Attach the two smaller MWR antennas

Glue or weld the two smaller MWR antennas onto the top right side of the main spacecraft body as shown

Step 5: Attach the Waves antenna

Flip the model over.

Glue or weld the Waves antenna to the main spacecraft body on the top bottom. The antenna should be attached at the 90 degree bend point and aligned so that it is symmetric about the solar panel.

Step 6: Paint (optional)

The final step (optional) is to use some paint to replicate Juno's actual colors. You will need red, blue, black, and silver paint. You may want to experiment with mixing silver and black for a darker silver color, and mix the black, red, and silver for the solar panels.

Give it a "shine" by applying a few layers of clear-coat spray paint.

print_settings.Notes:: This would probably print fine at a lower resolution, and the spacers definitely will.

I saw one similar to this some time ago but the teeth were to close together and while it was a great idea it just did not work. I have designed a few Barbers combs in the past (for barbershop use out of sprint steel) and so I thought I would give this a try. After a few revisions I came up with this design that works pretty good.  
It's not going to replace your home comb but when you are out and need a quick comb this will work and since it fits in a credit card slot in your wallet you will never be without.

I printed with a .35mm nozzle .2mm layer height. If the times don't fill in just tell your slicer the nozzle is slightly smaller so it thinks they will fit. In my case I changed the nozzle size to .30mm instead of .35mm and the tines filled in perfect.  
You will likely need to run a file in between the tines just to clean them up a little. Or you could do a vapor bath if you print in ABS.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. It was originally for a school project but I thought it woul be a fun thing to post, so thats that. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/amDSn6JsvtU

author: azerie

title: Replicator 2 / 2X Chassis corner plugs / passive contaminant reduction

description.text: These are trivial little plugs for the gaps in the Replicator 2 / 2X chassis top corners. These have been created to literally "plug a leak" for the "Air scrubbber that really works" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:125264). Without them there is a consistent convection leak of fumes that over hours creates a detectable odour near your printer even with the scrubber. These and a simple tweak (see instructions) can also significantly reduce your external air contamination even without an active filter

These plugs block the leakage from the top corners of the chassis. You might also like them for cosmetic reasons (trivial) - but combined with some simple coverings at the back of the hood I suspect even without the scrubber you will significantly reduce external pollution. Note that one of the plugs is different - it goes in the back right hand corner where there is a different internal clearance. I used clear acetate film cut to fit the rear hood - along with double sided tape - to restrict the rear airflows. (See the third photo) Used with the active air scrubber (Thing 125262), it now allows lower scrubber fan rates, improving the efficiency and life of the filters. Even without the scrubber I think it likely that it significantly improves "pollution" - and with the scrubber, I detect no external contamination even when the printer runs all day. (But my nose may not be all that good! ;-) ) My hypothesis is that the active printer generates a "hot cap" of air in the top of the hood that convects through the chassis as it cools. There is active mixing going on from the extruder fans which complicates this of course. The hot - and most contaminated - air being at the top of the chassis, the external convection loss from the corners is significant. With this blocked some of the cooling air will drop out the back of the hood - hence the addition of the covering sheets there. Without the scrubber there is room for some air to leak out that route but I suspect a lot of the vapour nasties sublimate as they move through that cooler region. With the scrubber, there is likely to be no loss from this route as there will be a mild internal negative pressure; most of the air will now leave via the scrubber after filtration. Which means pretty clean air relative to not using this kit!

print_settings.Notes:: Allow yourself plenty of time when making this suit because the time required for printing and finishing the components is significant.

description.text:
Apollo astronaut suit components that I designed for a fancy dress party.

Components were designed from historical photographs of the Apollo program space suits. Reference photographs used were from the Lunar Surface Journal.

The neck ring is the largest component at 30cm in diameter. This has been broken into 4 separate pieces to allow for printing on the majority of printers.

Printer:

XYZprinting Da Vinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

A high infill percentage is not required for these components. However, ensure that the number of top layers is increased (I used 5 top layers) to prevent sagging of the top layer due to the low infill percentage.

Allow yourself plenty of time when making this suit because the time required for printing and finishing the components is significant.

Finishing

Smooth the surfaces using sand paper. Start with a coarse sandpaper of 80grit and progressively move up to higher grits. I focused on making sure the top surfaces had a smooth finish.

The four quarters of the neck ring need to be assembled together carefully. Ensure that the adjacent edges of the four segments remain parallel to each other when sanding. Once the four segments assemble together well, glue the segments together with superglue.

Use a clean cloth to remove all sanding dust from the parts. Apply a light coat of spray-paint primer that is suitable for use on plastics - Dulux Duramax plastic primer worked well for me.

Once the primer has dried, apply a red or blue spray paint to match the anodising used in the original Apollo space suits.

The metallic spray paint I used needed to be thoroughly shaken to ensure the metallic compound mixed correctly with the paint inside the can, otherwise the objects had a matte colour finish. A minimum of 3 coats of paint was required.

Metallic Sharpie pens were used for the silver and gold detail on the components.

For the mission patch, NASA emblem, name tag and American flag, these were printed on labels that were stuck to the suit. Dimensions of the mission patch and NASA emblem were found here.

As for the name tag font, searching forums found that the name tag font was most likely "Futura Condensed".

Once all the components were printed and painted, they were super glued to a white disposable coverall suit. When buying the coverall suit, there are different types. The cheaper coverall suits used for painting don't have an white opaque outside liner and will not look as good. Choose a coverall that would be used for chemical removal as these have an opaque white exterior.

My Crafting New Industries project was inspired by my love of skateboards, even though I am pretty terrible at riding them despite the fact that I have been riding all different kinds since I was about 7.

After reading the prompt for this assignment, I got to thinking about the wide variety of skateboard, longboard, and cruiser decks and cool it would be to be able to fully customize a board. Right now there are means to customization that range from semi to highly customizable, such as going to a store like Zumiez and picking a starting deck, then picking the trucks and wheels, or a website such as http://www.pennyskateboards.com/ that has a built-in 3D Penny Customizer where the customer can go on, pick a size for their board, choose a design or color, for the board, the griptape, and the panel underneath and then choose what color the trucks and wheels should be. You can even choose the color of the bolts. With 3D printing, this kind of 3D customizer can be taken even further by letting the customer choose not only from two sizes of boards but hundreds of different types and shapes of boards as well as engravings of sort etched into the desks themselves before things are painted or even using CNC milling to engrave the boards after printing to create custom and unique boards.

Boards can be made out of plastic, though I am not sure exactly what type, but in the future, there might even be more efficient ways to print a mix of sawdust and plastic or even just wood. This would made for interesting textures and possibly even different kinds of boards. In this context, a customer would be able to start the process in which they communicate with the business by picking a material for their deck. They would then be able to choose from a few starting types and styles of boards before being able to contact the buyer about extremely customizing the shape or size of the deck. They would be able to do everything that is on the Penny Boards site, in terms of color customizations, but the trucks would be able to be printed on spot out of metal as well, and so different trucks would be able to be made for different types of boards to best fit each customer as well.

I’m not sure what kind of plastic standard wheels are made out of but in the future, different sizes and riding styles of wheels will also be able to be printed in-house and will print rather quickly.

Different painted designs could be printed onto the bottom of the decks with machines similar to the hamburger print demonstration as well.

With all this customization, a customer could get really creative with designs and styles and end up getting the exact kind of board that they want.

So what I have here are a few prototypes based on the idea of initially choosing your style of board before going more deeply into different designs and then maybe even taking it further with even more specific alterations that would require contacting the creator. I focused mainly on the different sizes and styles of riding, and then focused more deeply on different cut out designs for the tails of boards because I find this stuff super interesting. There are some super cool boards out there with really wacky tails.

These are just rough ideas as to the kinds of things that could be created with this type of 3D printing business/industry somewhere in the (hopefully) near future.

ART 297 - Project 10: "Crafting New Industries"

This is my first attempt at a Customizer thing. It is a business card that prints on both front and back of the card and uses dual extrusion. The front text is raised, but the back text must be flush with the card.

The *.scad file supports a company logo, but I couldn't figure out how to add to customizer. I was able to export logo using "path2scad" plug-in for Inkscape. If you have OpenSCAD locally, you can manually insert your own company logo.

I chose a font I think would look best in customizer. If you download *.scad and run locally, switch font flag to use local font instead.

I'll try to post some better pictures later. My printer jammed for the first time in months, so need to fix that first.

Tips:

  • on my printer, the smallest I could print the font was 4mm.
  • for back of card, slow down print speed. I used 25mm/sec
  • for back of card, use extruder 0 for text and 1 for the card. The card in photo was printed other way around and doesn't look right. I'll try to add photo of good card (once I do some printer maintenance)
  • filament matters a lot for how thick the card will be. I'm using Hatchbox-white (very good) and a no-name brand (so-so) that came free with my printer kit.
  • .4 (Card Z/depth) was thinnest I tried (one-side print). It worked well, but was almost translucent
  • the card in photo was printed with 1mm (Card Z/depth) and looks good for 2 sided print, but I think 1.2 would be better

I'm still very new at this (just got my 3d printer in Feb 2016), so I'm sure there are techniques I haven't learned yet.

description.text:
This cover replaces the stock cover of my Li Hua 24V power supply, 110mm x 195mm, holes in the side about 58mm and 180 from the end without terminals, and on the end with holes, holes spaced 90mm apart. They offered other PSUs with the same case, and given how PSUs are cloned and relabeled, you might find other brand PSUs this would work with, without changes, I don't know.

I designed it around a 15mm thick, 80mm square fan. I did this so I can use a quieter fan. I do intend to find a passively cooled PSU but this will do for me for now.

The stock fan is 12V despite the fact it is a 24V PSU. There was a 0.1" pin pair, pulling off the original jack housing allowed using the connector already on my fan.

I suggest using a finger guard on the fan exhaust. Mine still hasn't arrived yet.

Doing this removes RFI protection of and from your PSU, and possibly changes the cooling flow within the case, so use at your own risk.

Printer:

MendelMax 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm-0.3mm

Infill:

solid

Notes:

I print with 0.5mm wide bead width, two perimeters and 10 top and bottom layers so the cover and edges are solid with any layer setting.

The whole part is 2mm thick everywhere except the mounting screw holes.

Drill

Drill out the mounting holes to 2.8mm I used #34. 7/64" should be good. It might not need to be predrilled, I do it to prevent excess pressure from cracking the part.

I used Tsojcanth's awesome Wormy Trampier font - https://tsojcanth.wordpress.com/2016/03/31/new-font-pg-trampier-runes/

This set of files generate the printable parts needed to build a small linear carriage. This carriage is designed to be a Z axis carriage while http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1411601 is the Y axis. The X axis will be uploaded soon. It can be heavily customized.

The Libre Office Calc file is used to compute some key values needed to create the printable parts. Some resulting values have a variable name on the right. These values shall be copied into the Parameters.scad file. It is the only OpenScad file that contains modifiable parameters.

Once you have customized the parameters in Parameters.scad, open the files "Front Plate.scad", "Motor Mount.scad" and "BearingHousingMount.scad" with OpenScad, render them and export the three models. Before printing or cutting material, verify carefully the overall part sizes. Invalid parts may be generated if incoherent values are inputted.

The value given in the given files are for:

20 x 20 mm V-SLOT™ Linear rail (337 mm in length)
1 Nema17 stepper motor (17HS8401)
4 Delrin V Wheel™ Kit with spacers
1 8 mm lead screw (four starts) easily available from Chinese suppliers
1 flexible 8mm - 5mm coupler
2 608ZZ bearings with a 8 mm washer
2 T-Slot inserts with the required M5 screws (10 mm)
4 M3 screws to mount the motor (8 mm)
5 M5 screws and nuts to mount the V Wheels (25 mm)
2 M3 screws and nuts to mount the nut bracket. (10 mm)

Mount the bearing housing without the bearing in the housing first.

description.text:
This is a design for a dual extruder with a simple magnetic coupling, inspired by OpenCircuitDesign's Makergear M2 twin extruder. Essentially, there are 3 parts to it: a middle block to which the belt is affixed and a left and right block that carry the hotends (E3D v6s). The middle block is spaced so that it cannot attach to both the left and right blocks at once, so through some G-code manipulation it's able to detach and reattach to either block without any extra electronics. This allows for each hotend to be manipulated and compensated for separately similar to dual X carriages, which might be able to eliminate ooze and hotend leveling issues.

Visit this link for OpenCircuitDesign's original article and an explanation of the principles behind it:
http://opencircuitdesign.com/~tim/3d_printer/twin_project/index.html

Project is a work in progress: it's still missing the two parking points on either side of the X rods and no prototype has yet been printed because I'm still awaiting magnets.

description.text:
This Effector Platform for the Rostock Max V2 was designed to incorporate the following design elements:

  1. Use the new ball-joint arms
  2. Use an E3Dv6 Hot End
  3. Incorporate a light (in this case a 70mm 'angel eyes' from aliexpress)
  4. Incorporate layer fan mounts with internal ducts that aims cooling airflow from all directions just below the nozzle (so it cools the plastic but does not affect the nozzle temperature as the fans start and stop).
  5. Be as compact and rigid as possible and maintain the original build envelope (and be aesthetically pleasing!)

I originally started modifying the design by jimustanguitar to add a light and the ball joints, but ended up starting again from scratch. Full credit and thanks to his original design for the concept I built from.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100 percent

Notes:

Printed @ 0.2mm layer height with a 0.4mm nozzle using ABS with 100 percent infill.

The only support I used is for the 'roof' of the light-ring slot. This is covered by the light ring once it's installed so any affect on surface finish to that part of the print isn't seen. Don't let the slicer put supports inside the ducts - You'll never get them out! If you can't select where the support goes then print without any support at all.

Brass screw inserts are melted into the bottom of the platform (inside the angel-eyes mounting slot) at the 6 locations that secure the ball-joint arms. They are inserted from the bottom as they provide much more strength being in the main body than in the thin locating studs that locates the ball-joints on the top.

The 'angel eyes' light-ring snaps into place and is held by three lugs. It is not glued or screwed.

I lightly sanded the surface of the effector and then wiped with a soft cloth dipped in acetone to smooth it ( I don't have a vapor bath setup yet). Not necessary, just personal choice.
Designed in 123D design

description.text:
I created this bracket to mount my soundbar to the top of my LCD TV to keep it out of reach of my young daughter (she has just started standing and grabbing things lol!).

The soundbar looks much more tidy on top of the TV then it did before sitting in front of the TV IMHO.

The STL is set up for my Samsung soundbar:
Width: 60.2 mm
Height: 55.2 mm

and Hisense LCD TV:
Width (at top): 25.5 mm
Width (at bottom): 29.5 mm

I have included the sketchup file so the dimensions can be modified to suit. With my printer I have spent a long while calibrating to achieve fairly accurate printed dimensions and I added on about 0.5mm to the actual measurements of my soundbar/TV. Clips onto the soundbar and TV nicely.

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

No

0.2

30%

I printed this in PLA.

The STL model height is 15mm which I found to be much thicker than necessary. I scaled the z height of the model in Cura to 8mm which is still more than enough as the weight of the soundbar is sitting pretty balanced on the TV anyway.

One of my biggest gripes with my TOM is the constant stripping of the filament when printing things with lots of reversals (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12034 SnowFlake is my hardcore test these days) Thinking that a adjustable pressure and a free wheeling follower would work better I printed out the http://www.thingiverse.com/14468 Shaputer modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7113 Yet another extruder filament drive by Jag Definitely a step in the right direction, but now instead of stripping the filament would fatigue and start wrapping around the driver. In the comments on Jag's drive someone mentioned they thought the 1.75mm filament was just too weak, which it is, what it needs is more support, so I modified Jag's driver to move the plastic up as close to the driver as I could and still get good pressure on the filament. Here's the results, I'm just finishing a print of the Snow Flake as I type this, I wasn't even able to get half way through before even with the Jag drive. I also made the nut slots a big bigger to try and save some time.

Print and fit
it may take a bit of carving with a to get everything in and smooth

Hare are my designs for custom parts on the E3D Bigbox printer.

Thanks to Ephemeris at the E3D forums for the initial Nut trap clip design. Forum thread:
https://forum.e3d-online.com/index.php?threads/simple-retainer-for-nut-traps.882/

The nut trap clip I printed with layer height at 0.25 and width 0.4. Pretty slow printing because of the small details. I spent 3 - 4 hours printing 70 clips.

Thanks to JvdP on the E3D forums for his "Project Whisper" Making BigBox Quiet thread. You can find more info on silencing the Bigbox here:
https://forum.e3d-online.com/index.php?threads/project-whisper-making-bigbox-quiet.914/

The temp probe for RUMBA fits on top of the JTAG connector and is a tight fit. You might have to lower extrusion rate if it is too tight. Try different extrusion widths to get it right.

Update: I had misunderstood where the exhaust fan would be located. I have removed the exhaust fan bracket.

I was working on some Lego Mindstorm with my son over the holidays and there was one beam/part that we just didn't have - and it would seem that it is non-standard and you can't buy a similar part anywhere. I suppose we could have re-deigned our whole robot around the parts that we did have, but...

In the true maker spirit, I just down loaded Open S CAD, searched for a Lego Technic compatible design (thanks Brian Jepson!), hacked it around until it looked like what I needed and made my first 3D model :)

I needed to explain how I did this to my son, which meant I needed a better idea of how it works myself! So I have spent the past couple of days learning (enough) about Open S CAD. In the process I have made many enhancements to the code I found online. It can now handle many more use cases and is generally a lot neater (IMHO).

My main concern with the original code was that it was full of "magic numbers" scattered through-out the code. I have now named every aspect of the geometry to a variable, and all variables are declared in the one place at the top of the main library.

Also in my research I found that when subtracting one solid from another, the 2 solids should not share a common surface. That is, you should never draw a cube 10 units high and then subtract a cylinder 10 units high. If you do, it results in an infinitely thin surface which is both defined as "there" and "not there". This can seriously mess with the generation of the printer file.

The correct solution is to always subtract something that either fully penetrates through the original surface, or stops short of the original surface. This has also now been fixed for all parts of the models.

It has been an interesting couple of days learning a bit about solid modelling - something I have never had need to try before.

Hopefully this work may be of use / interest to other makes. Enjoy.

comments.text: Thanks, and it is nice that you took the time to clean up code for the rest of us!

description.text:
This is one of my first Things! I was looking for a desiccant container that would fit into the center of my PLA spools, but could not find. So, I made one and learned some Sketchup in the process.

I think it goes without saying that you would need to also store your spools in airtight containers for this to be of any use.

I added lots of repeating cutout text. Please excuse the odd letters, they just seemed to be a good choice for something that wouldn't let the silica gel beads through; also my name starts with G.

I've printed this several times, one for each new color of PLA that I have. The first iteration didn't have any room for error on the lid portion and the lids would not stick or stick too well sometimes so this model gives an extra .25mm for each gripping side of the snap-on lid. If your printer prints things perfectly, you may need to scale the cap accordingly.

description.text:
This is an upgrade for the stock spool holder design to add a guided offset for the spool of the back of the BigBox case.

The stock design works good for normal spools although I had an issue with black spools leaving black scratches in my polar white case which looks not very nice.
The design definitely failed for me with 2.2kg productions spools from Colorfabb because the spool has a much bigger diameter so the spool can get in contact with the protruding screw heads.

To mount the spacers you need M3x30 screws instead of the M3x20, for one spool holder you need two spacers and 6 screws.

The second part, spool holder clamp, is not mandatory but recommended because of the increased distance the stock clamps are a bit short.
To build these you need a M4x40 screw instead of the stock M4x30. One for one clamp.

description.text:
The ST360 was an ultra cheap quadcopter frame that was popular a few years back. One of the hurdles owners had to overcome was finding a place to mount a battery as the frame legs were very short. There were a number of different solutions.

This is a shelf designed to sit over the flight controller, and provide room for a battery and a small camera. It leaves enough room for a KK2 flight controller, and can be attached through the existing holes using the same type of screws that the quadcopter arms use, or something similar.

This is the reason I built my RapMan :D
I've made a shell to go around a (heavily modified) Nerf Stampede to make it look like a 40k Bolter.
It's still fully functional, shoots darts and takes standard Nerf magazines (one day I'll do the Bolter magazine too)
Unfortunately it'll always be more a decorative piece, mostly due to it weighing 4kgs, making far too heavy to lug around all day during wars or HvZ :P
Not quite sure what's going on in the preview images for the .STL's, They printed out ok after a bit of rotating in Axon
(Obligatory Note: I don't own Nerf, or anything relating to GamesWorkshop/Warhammer, etc, I'm just a big fan of both)

The Stampede had to be minimised to make it fit, as shown in the picture comparing the lengths
For interest it's also running an aftermarket 9kg spring, and 2 banks (in parallel) of 4x Trustfire Lithium batteries for ~16v

title: Mendel90 EZStruder System - Direct Drive 1.75mm Solution

description.text: Parts neccessary to use an EZStruder 1.75mm direct drive extuder on a Mendel90 with stock ducted cooling, adding 40mm jhead cooling for 1.75mm PLA.

The "System" consists of 3 pieces so far:
  • modified x carriage (with spot for 40mm fan)
  • ezstruder to carriage adaptor
  • fan shroud to direct jhead fan above Mendel90 cooling duct

title: Drop-in t-slot nuts for 8mm slots (30mm profile)

description.text:
I needed some drop in nuts for 30mm aluminum extrusion profile and found the original from #whosawhatsis with the Open Scad source. So I modified a bit to fit my profiles.

It is still for M3 nuts and bolts but I rotated the nut and bolt hole 30 degree to allow for a better overhanging prints.

Also, I added a slot to allow the nuts to be turned with a flat-head screwdriver.

title: 3-extruder base with LCD controller stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This design feels very bendy, because of the thin base, but the 8mm acryl edge it sits on, makes it sufficiently sturdy.
The long legs serve to bridge the hole onderneath, which again is very handy to guide the teflon tubes through.

In the first print of the design I made the holes for the fittings a bit small, so the thread in them is at risk.
As you can see in the pictures it went wrong with the middle one, but it was easy to make the hole a bit greater.
I have adapted the design, so the fittings get straight on to the extruder-house.

The LCD controller-box is from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1116163, with thanks.

author: cupid101

description.text: These X-Ends build on prusajr's and my previous work to add a few neat features. I found with the original prusa X-ends that the screws that held the x rods would slip when you tightened the X belt and that would pull the PLA bushings off the Z rods. You get a similar problem with LM8uu X ends but instead of pulling them off the rods, they flex the Z rods and as a result can cause the Z axiz to bind when you raise it closer to where the Z rods are constrained by the frame. The push fit X ends sort of address the issue, but you would need to cut the length of the X rods very precisely. This design has one X end closed and one open (but closeable by the insertion of a screw or piece of 3mm filament). The closed end has a nut trap in the end so that you can install a tensioning screw. That allows you to precisely set the separation of the X ends and have them held rigidly at that distance regardless of the tensioning of the X belt without the need to cut the rods precisely. The open X end allows you to slide the X rods all the way out (once you remove the locking screw/filament) to easily replace or service your X carriage/extruder. The x-end-motor has another new neat feature which is a platform that allows you to screw adjust the height of an endstop landing pad. This should make adjusting the Z endstop (which is the only one that needs adjusting accurately) much simpler. I found that it was very much trial and error adjusting the traditional endstops because not only did they slide up and down the rods, but they would also tilt slightly which also affected their set-point. Getting them adjusted accurately was an exercise in frustration. To use the Z adjustment, you need to remove the support section of the adjustment column, then insert the captive nut and screw and tighten the screw until it flexes the landing pad down slightly. Then set your Z stop a bit low and iterate the process of adjusting the screw and homing the Z until you are happy with the home position. I put a nut in both the top and bottom nut traps, but strictly speaking, only the bottom nut is essential. I have also shaved off the bump on the motor mount so that I can use 10 tooth machined T5 pullies instead of printed 8mm pullies without the belt rubbing on the bump. There is also an optional x endstop mount on the x-end-motor that allows you to use an automotive/cherry microswitch (the kind that has 3mm mounting holes) so that you don't need special hardware to mount your endstops, you can just use m3 screws. Incorporating the endstop in the X end also allows you to maximize x travel. This can be good if you print on glass or have a build plate without a purge area to allow the x home to be off the platform so you can wipe the nozzle and do any pre-print priming. Checkout the pic from the top with the X at its home position. There is literally no travel wasted. The model is parametric to allow for you to use 2 lm8uu or 1 lm8luu in each X end. I have uploaded both varieties. Please refer to my github for the OpenSCAD source files: https://github.com/GregFrost/PrusaMendel

author: mpaiard

description.text:
Micro quad designed around micro scisky, spektrum va1100 camera.

Quad rests at a 15 degree angle. When in forward flight camera (and cargo platform are level).

Print the frame and the cargo plate (not the assembled version - that's just for illustration).

To assemble use 3 rubber bands. Two of them attach the cargo plate to the frame and one is to hold the FC in place. Adjust the two frame bands so that the cargo plate's top is flush with the front motors.

I'm using both the tenergy 350 1S and the mylipo.de 450 1S. In either case use the rearmost two rubber bands to hold them in place. The batter is supposed to be close to the rear of the cargo plate to balance the whole quad.

Separate SCAD files for frame and plate can be found here: https://github.com/hagleitn/fast_forward

Udpate May 9th:

After some test flying with the original frame (v3, 11cm), decided to make a slightly larger frame with a more pronounced angle (20deg, 13cm). The original frame gave me some vibrations, the larger frame is more solid in the air. Still zips around pretty good :-)

description.text: This is a 7 card holder for a Lulzbot TAZ 5 printer, though I think it will also fit the 4.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.38

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I went pretty fast on this print - 140mm/s, which took about an hour all in all. Going down to something like 80mm/s is almost certainly going to produce a nicer finish, but as it's a printer accessory I don't mind a slightly rougher look.

WilliamAAdams's roundedRect

I made use of WilliamAAdams's roundedRect function which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9347. I did modify it slightly to match more closely the results of using the standard cube() function.
